bestBHT.bht: This phrase, they that are whole, describes those who are in good health, as commonly used in medical writings. Conversely, they that are sick refers to individuals who require a physician. This draws a parallel between physical and spiritual well-being. It suggests that those who consider themselves righteous may actually be in need of spiritual healing, while those who acknowledge their own sinfulness are the ones who require the divine Physician.

Marvin Vincent: This use of the verb in its primary sense, to be in sound health, is found in Luke 7:10; Luke 14:27; and once in John, 3 Ep. verse 2.
For this meaning it is the regular word in medical writings.
Archibald T. Robertson: They that are whole (ο υγιαινοντες). Old Greek word for good health from υγιης, sound in body.
This is the usual word for good health used by Greek medical writers.
Mark 2:17; Matthew 9:12 have ο ισχυοντες (those who have strength).
John Gill: They that are whole need not a physician, but they that are sick.

They, the Scribes and Pharisees, who, in their own opinion, were free from the disease of sin, stood not in any need of him, the physician, who came to cure the maladies of the souls, as well as of the bodies of men.
His business, as a physician, lying among the one, and not the other.

bhtAttempts.bht: This verse speaks to the idea that those who are in good health do not need a physician, while those who are sick require one. The phrase they that are whole is used here, which refers to those who are in sound health. This word is commonly used in medical writings and signifies good health. On the other hand, they that are sick refers to those who are in need of a physician. This verse draws a parallel between physical health and spiritual well-being, implying that those who believe they are righteous and free from sin are in fact in need of spiritual healing, while those who recognize their own sinfulness and inadequacy are the ones who require the divine Physician.

In this passage, the phrase they that are whole is used to describe those who are in good health. This term is commonly found in medical writings and denotes sound physical well-being. Conversely, they that are sick refers to individuals in need of a physician. This verse draws a parallel between physical health and spiritual restoration, suggesting that those who perceive themselves as righteous may actually be in need of spiritual healing, while those who acknowledge their own sinfulness are the ones who require the divine Physician.
